Kingdom Two Crowns is highly geared to a very, very specific audience. I really like tower defense, and I really like resource management so this game was a hit for me despite some pretty heavy flaws.

The first is time. You're running back and forth, back and forth, back and forth, looking for resources/waiting for your peasants to spawn them after finding free ones in the land around you. As islands get larger that problem does too, unless you're playing with a friend which helps mitigate it. It's also very repetitive not only in gameplay loop as mentioned but also in the environment. It's all predetermined spots for where you're building and what. That can create some small challenges(ex. you can't keep cutting and building right in front of enemy portals, or the spawn point for a wall is inconvenient by taking up a lot of empty space best used for wild grass yielding rabbits/whatever takes it's place in other expansions) but that fades away into tedium too.

The games built-in timer(the intensity and breed of Greed that attack your base) is pretty solid until you endgame an island where the enemies are all the basic weaker form in a really straightforward quest.

The devs have a surprising amount of extra content and DLC which are mostly texture reworks with the same mechanics. Which is fine! They look great just like the base game! but there's only so much you can get out of it. I liked Kingdom Two Crowns as my 'I need something idle to do with my hands while I watch something' game, and I think I've exhausted that for myself. I would prefer this around $10 USD/50% off.

Tips and tricks for the interested:

-The game has a very bad time of explaining mechanics. You have limited space in the pouch in the top right of the screen for your currency, Greed spawn nightly to attack, anything that costs Gems(spawning from large, ornate chests. Not on your first island) has some ability you should probably look up, you cannot attack Greed spawn points until you have a more organized militia

-Get off that first island as soon as possible because to create a militia to fight Greed spawn points, you need stone. Stone mines are available on the second island and carry across all islands once you unlock it

-My favorite mount is the Bear, until you attack an islands ultimate Greed spawner. Then I swap to something a little faster, like my original mount

-Get as many people as you can to generate archers, and clear land so that it becomes wild grassland attracting rabbits they hunt daily for coins

-Winter changes mechanics, I advise having pike men not only for defense but for small coin gain

Winter is [strike]ass[/strike] boring, paid DLC achivements on the main game are [strike]ass[/strike] unfair
Everything else is good

negative.review: This game is OK for the first couple hours, but once you've figured out the mechanics it's literally the exact same thing on every single island. You don't get to decide where to build things, the spots and buildings are pre-defined. You go from one island to another and fight the exact same enemy over and over. It's quite boring once you've destroyed the first few islands.

Kingdom Two Crowns is built for a specific fanbase, and only that fanbase and that's okay. It's gorgeous, polished, and atmospheric but the gameplay design is infuriating.

My main gripe is that the 'challenge' of this game comes not from any sense of difficulty, but intentionally bad game design that you'll spend more time fighting than enjoying. 

- Gold (main currency) you can only carry very limited amounts of, is very easy to obtain and very difficult to store. This results in massive amounts of gold despawning as you travel back and forth across the island. I *cannot* overstate how infuriating this becomes after your farmers toss well over 50 gold at you and it all despawns.
- Can take up to 5 full minutes to run all the way across the islands that you'll be managing, which will be a very frequent and necessary occurrence. Doesn't help that they gave your mounts stamina mechanics, which serve only to slow this further.
- The Peasant AI is very stupid. They'll gather far from jobsites, and bunch up right outside the outer walls so if the walls fall they'll suffer losses. Low self preservation instinct, meaning that you'll have to plan their jobs so their done by nightfall so they don't get jumped. Really most of the strategy for this game ends up being timing the day/night cycle, and micromanaging jobs to make sure the AI doesn't do anything stupid.
- The game does not explain anything about itself, which isn't always a bad thing, but it serves only to hide the lack of variety in the game. After 6 hours of very similar gameplay, I looked online to see that there wasn't much I hadn't already seen. I can't confirm, but from what I understand the other 'Themes' don't drastically change the base game either.

It's a cute game, and I adore the aesthetics, but all that glitters is not gold. Graphics isn't gameplay and this game doesn't hold its own. Its minimal UI and lack of info or tutorials just hide the fact that there just isn't much here.

The game has great visuals, but it's let down by its punishing nature and unclear mechanics.

It heavily penalizes you for small mistakes ‚Äî yours or even an NPC's, without providing clear guidance. For example, buildings and NPCs don't have any descriptions of their purpose, leaving you to guess why you need to upgrade them or give them a particular profession. There's also no way to undo most of your actions, that prevents you from experimenting and learning the game yourself.

To finally understand the game's logic and stop feeling punished, I had to restart multiple times and rely on external online tutorials. I think this shouldn't be necessary to enjoy a game.

Another major issue is the early-game economy. You're often left with nothing to do but wait for residents to generate income until farmers are available, which is especially frustrating at the beginning of each new island.

Overall, I expected a much more player-friendly experience.

Kingdom Two Crowns is built for a specific fanbase, and only that fanbase and that's okay. It's gorgeous, polished, and atmospheric but the gameplay design is infuriating.

My main gripe is that the 'challenge' of this game comes not from any sense of difficulty, but intentionally bad game design that you'll spend more time fighting than enjoying. 

- Gold (main currency) you can only carry very limited amounts of, is very easy to obtain and very difficult to store. This results in massive amounts of gold despawning as you travel back and forth across the island. I *cannot* overstate how infuriating this becomes after your farmers toss well over 50 gold at you and it all despawns.
- Can take up to 5 full minutes to run all the way across the islands that you'll be managing, which will be a very frequent and necessary occurrence. Doesn't help that they gave your mounts stamina mechanics, which serve only to slow this further.
- The Peasant AI is very stupid. They'll gather far from jobsites, and bunch up right outside the outer walls so if the walls fall they'll suffer losses. Low self preservation instinct, meaning that you'll have to plan their jobs so their done by nightfall so they don't get jumped. Really most of the strategy for this game ends up being timing the day/night cycle, and micromanaging jobs to make sure the AI doesn't do anything stupid.
- The game does not explain anything about itself, which isn't always a bad thing, but it serves only to hide the lack of variety in the game. After 6 hours of very similar gameplay, I looked online to see that there wasn't much I hadn't already seen. I can't confirm, but from what I understand the other 'Themes' don't drastically change the base game either.

It's a cute game, and I adore the aesthetics, but all that glitters is not gold. Graphics isn't gameplay and this game doesn't hold its own. Its minimal UI and lack of info or tutorials just hide the fact that there just isn't much here.

This game can be fun. Its a scroll side type of game. You're defenseless, only having your mount about you. You cannot fight, you cannot run. Eventually, you'll run out of room to run to. And the little purple minions will consume you.

However, despite that, you do have coins, you have a kingdom to build. You have land to conquer, and room to explore. The game, and its music slowly grows on you, but its limited by the vison of the developers. Its fun, exciting at times, but frustrating as well. You see, the game lacks quality of life changes that's needed to really enjoy the game.

Yes, you could mod the game, but the developers update the game so much it breaks the mods entirely. In truth, from what i've learned in terms of mod support, it seems the developers don't want people to add changes that would naturally improve the game. But also make it easier. 

The quality changes the game lacks is simple.
1. When your defenders are attacked, they should not take one punch then just give up.
2. There's points in the game where its actually harder to get civilians because of the slow spawn rates per tents. Yes you can purchase them for five coins, but often times, especially during winter, your low on coins. 
3. When you lose a wall, the snowball effect begins.  Your only defense is the archers posted in the tower, and there's no hotkey to put archers in the tower, you just either have to spam archers, or hope they get up there on their own. 

The list goes on and on. Now,  there  were some mods to change this, the one that allows civlians to walk freely without you having to buy them, that mod works at the moment. (At the time of me writing this 12/2/2025). 

After you destroy a portal, the game gets boring, because there's no mods that work because the devs want to keep the game like they created it. You want a harder experience? Can't get a mod for that. You want a deeper sack (No pun intended) A mod would fix that, and there's one out there that does exist, buts its busted because of the recent updates.

So there you have it. I would only purchase this game on sale. And only on sale until the devs realize that the mods are for the community, and not for them

I have played the original games before:
‚Ä¢ [b]23.3 hours[/b]  in [i]Kingdom: Classic[/i]
‚Ä¢ [b]68.8 hours[/b] in [i]Kingdom: New Lands[/i]

That was nearly a decade ago, when I was in my early 20s and had time to waste on silly indie games.
Today, as a guy in my 30s, this formula just does not click anymore. The gameplay feels extremely limited. You move left or right, pick up a couple of beggars, chop some trees, and repeat. There is very little agency or variation, and the loop gets old fast.

Sure, [i]Kingdom Two Crowns[/i] can be a nice detox from high-octane FPS and competitive shooters. The pixel art, water reflections, and music are all beautiful. But after a while, your patience and your fingers start to hurt from holding down [b]A/D + Shift[/b] just to move around.

After all these years, I expected more quality-of-life improvements.
For example:
‚Ä¢ Double-tapping [b]A[/b] or [b]D[/b] could make your ruler automatically move instead of holding the key down for minutes.
‚Ä¢ A game speed or delta-time option (like [i]Stronghold[/i] with ‚Äú+‚Äù or ‚Äú‚Äì‚Äù) would help a lot.

This game can be fun. Its a scroll side type of game. You're defenseless, only having your mount about you. You cannot fight, you cannot run. Eventually, you'll run out of room to run to. And the little purple minions will consume you.

However, despite that, you do have coins, you have a kingdom to build. You have land to conquer, and room to explore. The game, and its music slowly grows on you, but its limited by the vison of the developers. Its fun, exciting at times, but frustrating as well. You see, the game lacks quality of life changes that's needed to really enjoy the game.

Yes, you could mod the game, but the developers update the game so much it breaks the mods entirely. In truth, from what i've learned in terms of mod support, it seems the developers don't want people to add changes that would naturally improve the game. But also make it easier. 

The quality changes the game lacks is simple.
1. When your defenders are attacked, they should not take one punch then just give up.
2. There's points in the game where its actually harder to get civilians because of the slow spawn rates per tents. Yes you can purchase them for five coins, but often times, especially during winter, your low on coins. 
3. When you lose a wall, the snowball effect begins.  Your only defense is the archers posted in the tower, and there's no hotkey to put archers in the tower, you just either have to spam archers, or hope they get up there on their own. 

The list goes on and on. Now,  there  were some mods to change this, the one that allows civlians to walk freely without you having to buy them, that mod works at the moment. (At the time of me writing this 12/2/2025). 

After you destroy a portal, the game gets boring, because there's no mods that work because the devs want to keep the game like they created it. You want a harder experience? Can't get a mod for that. You want a deeper sack (No pun intended) A mod would fix that, and there's one out there that does exist, buts its busted because of the recent updates.

So there you have it. I would only purchase this game on sale. And only on sale until the devs realize that the mods are for the community, and not for them

The game has great visuals, but it's let down by its punishing nature and unclear mechanics.

It heavily penalizes you for small mistakes ‚Äî yours or even an NPC's, without providing clear guidance. For example, buildings and NPCs don't have any descriptions of their purpose, leaving you to guess why you need to upgrade them or give them a particular profession. There's also no way to undo most of your actions, that prevents you from experimenting and learning the game yourself.

To finally understand the game's logic and stop feeling punished, I had to restart multiple times and rely on external online tutorials. I think this shouldn't be necessary to enjoy a game.

Another major issue is the early-game economy. You're often left with nothing to do but wait for residents to generate income until farmers are available, which is especially frustrating at the beginning of each new island.

Overall, I expected a much more player-friendly experience.
